title: Theory and Method in Islamic Studies
xlist:
Same As: RLST 716, section 01
Same As: RLST 454, section 01
Same As: NELC 420, section 01
Same As: MMES 405, section 01
yc_attrs: This course can be applied towards the Humanities and Arts Yale College distributional requirement.
description:
This seminar provides a broad overview of the professional study of Islam within the Western academy through an interrogation of the field as a discrete, analyzable discursive formation. Particular attention is paid to developments over the course of the last fifty years. Explored are major problems and areas of research, as well as various paradigms for situating Islamic Studies in the disciplinary frameworks of history, religion, anthropology, area studies, law, and sociology. Themes include: language, epistemology, authenticity, origins, Orientalism, revisionism, polemic, reform, secularism, gender, ritual, law, territory, material and visual cultures, enchantment, ethics, violence, vernacularity, new philology, the digital humanities, and the formation, reconstitution, and dissolution of disciplinary boundaries. Particular attention is paid to the methodological bases for the generation of knowledge, along with the various assumptions, values, and motivations governing the academic study of Islam in North America and Europe. Readings are drawn from current research, as well as an array of theoretical reflections produced within and beyond the field of Islamic Studies.
